definition: A *Garden of Eden* (briefly, [GoE]{}) for a cellular automaton $\Acal = \langle Q, \Neigh, f \rangle$ on a group $G$ is a configuration $c \in Q^G$ which is not in the image of the global function $F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}$ of ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}$. In other words, a Garden of Eden is a global situation which can be started from, but never returned to. The finitary counterpart of a [GoE]{} configuration is an *orphan pattern*: a pattern which cannot be obtained by synchronous application of the local function $f$. Of course, any cellular automaton with an orphan pattern also has a [GoE]{} configuration. \[lem:opp\] If a cellular automaton with finite set of states $Q$ has a [GoE]{} configuration, then it also has an orphan pattern. *Proof.* First, suppose that $G$ is countable. Let $\Acal = \langle Q, \Neigh, f \rangle$ be a cellular automaton with no orphan pattern. Let $c : G \to Q$ be a configuration: we will prove that there is some $e : G \to Q$ such that $F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}(e) = c$. Let $G = \{g_n\}_{n \geq 0}$ be an enumeration of $G$: put $E_n = \{g_i \mid i \leq n\}$ and let $p_n : E_n \to Q$ be defined as $p_n = \restrict{c}{E_n}.$ By hypothesis, none of the $p_n$’s is an orphan, so there is a sequence of configurations $c_n : G \to Q$ satisfying $\restrict{F_\Acal(c_n)}{E_n} = p_n = \restrict{c}{E_n}.$ It is easy to see that $\lim_{k \to \infty} F_\Acal(c_{n_k}) = c.$ But if $Q$ is finite, then $Q^G$ is compact by Tychonoff’s theorem, so there exista a subsequence $\{ c_{n_k} \}_{k \geq 0}$ and a configuration $e : G \to Q$ satisfying $\lim_{k \to \infty} c_{n_k} = e:$ Since $F_{\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}$ is continuous in the product topology, $F(e) = c$. Let now $G$ be arbitrary. Let $H$ be the subgroup generated by the neighborhood index ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}$: since ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{N}}}$ is finite, $H$ is countable. Let $J$ be a set of representatives of the left cosets of $H$ in $G$, so that $G = \bigsqcup_{j \in J} jH.$ (Observe that we do *not* require that $H$ is normal in $G$.) Call ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}_H$ the cellular automaton *on $H$* that has the same local description (set of states, neighborhood index, local function) as ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}$. Let $c : G \to Q$ be a Garden of Eden configuration for ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}$: then at least one of the configurations $c_j(h) = c(jh)$ must be a Garden of Eden for ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}_H$. By the discussion above, ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}_H$ must have an orphan pattern, which is also an orphan pattern for ${\ensuremath{\mathcal{A}}}$. $\Box$
